question: ...Because he's not.
answer: I do need one more thing, Charlie.

question: What's that?
answer: Someone to turn the goddamn homing device on. No signal, no score.

question: What's that shit?
answer: A book. It's called reading. You should try it some time.

question: You wanna read something. Read between the lines.
answer: Well here's something even you can relate to. Albert got a lotta trim. That genius thing is a babe magnet.

question: Hello?
answer: Hi, sweetie.

question: Daddy. How are you?
answer: I'm sending you something.

question: Really? Does it smell nice?
answer: No. But it's sparkly.

question: Does it come with a receipt?
answer: I'm having it sent to you from the store.

question: Why not bring it by yourself? We could have dinner.
answer: Be a long trip. I'm in Genoa.

question: Let me guess. Checking out the birthplace of Christopher Columbus.
answer: Something like that.

question: With your parole officer's approval.
answer: I think I've paid my P.O. my last visit. I liked the guy, but we never really connected.

question: What are you into, Dad? Don't break my heart. You told me you were through.
answer: After this, I swear to you, I am.

question: You promised me. Daddy, don't do this.
answer: Everything's going to be fine. I've got to go now. I love you. Bye. Italians?

question: I trust everyone. It's the devil inside them that I don't trust. Got a sec?
answer: My office.

question: How you feeling, boss?
answer: Fine. I'm fine, fine.

question: You know what fine, stands for, don't you? Fucked-up, Insecure, Neurotic, and Emotional.
answer: You've become quite the philosopher since you quit drinking.

question: You don't like me sober?
answer: No, I'm glad. Makes you a better thief.

question: For after the haul.
answer: Hope I get to fire it up. If Steve's Italians are a no-show, it's three months prep down the shitter and I've dragged you out of retirement for nothing.

question: This is kinda nice. You being the boss with all the worries, me just along for the ride.
answer: Ain't you sweet...

question: Ain't you sweet...
answer: Charlie!

question: Your Italians.
answer: Yup. Dixie cups.

question: Dixie cups?
answer: I toss 'em away if there's a problem down the road.

question: Sweet Jesus.
answer: "That for which all virtue is sold. And almost every vice -- gold." My name is John and I'm a very rich alcoholic. And I'm going to live my life one very rich day at a time. You planned this one down to a t, kid. It's a gift. You saw the big picture, made contingencies, covered the angles... Shit, you made thirty million dollars in gold drop out of sight without holding a gun. Who else could've pulled that off?

question: You could've. I had big shoes to fill.
answer: Fill the shoes but don't follow the footprints.

question: What're you talking about? You've lived the life.
answer: My life's been nothing but fake IDs, fake business cards and divorce papers. This is the only thing that's real.

question: Stella's a beautiful girl.
answer: She's amazing. And I spent half her childhood in prison. This is a once in a lifetime haul, Charlie. Bring down the curtain after this one. Make a new life. Find someone amazing and be there for her.

question: Anyone acts stupid and his brains go on the windshield.
answer: What the hell do you think you're doing?

question: Sorry Charlie. But I want the box of Cracker Jack all to myself.
answer: You're not thinking this through. It's a stupid move.

question: If you would have told me that I would spend the next three years searching for Steve Bandell, I would have said that was nothing. Cause I would have spent a lifetime looking for that bastard if I had to.
answer: Buzz of the fluorescents throws me off. She's all yours. Now you know who to call first. Well I do it for the money. I'll send you the bill. I never look. Bye, guys. Four minutes, forty-three seconds. So what's on the line-up? Tell him if I don't have it opened in six minutes flat, breakfast is on me. Charlie Croker.

question: Hi, Stella.
answer: Refresh my memory. After you came to see me and told me what happened to my father, I told you I never wanted to see you again, didn't I?

question: Yeah. You did.
answer: So I'm a little confused.

question: I found him. I can tell you where he is.
answer: I don't want to know.

question: Are you sure? He's in Los Angeles. The gold bricks he stole from us were minted in Singapore and decorated with the face of a Balinese girl. I've had my tentacles out and got a call from a friend of mine and your father's, Philly Steak.
answer: When I was little he would play poker at the house and drop quarters under the table for me to find.

question: He got word from an L.A. connection named Skinny Pete that a gold dealer has been buying bricks with the Balinese girl on them, three or four at a time.
answer: You ever heard the expression, cut to the chase?

question: I tracked Steve down to an address in the Hollywood Hills. He's changed his last name to Frezelli. And get this
answer: Precious or not, I don't deal with ill-gotten goods.

question: We boosted that gold from a terrorist group that was about to trade it for bio-weapons. Now that doesn't exactly make us Robin Hood, but maybe in our own little way we were doing a good deed. Problem is, no one in my crew can handle that safe. And I need someone I can trust.
answer: And you think that's me? Haven't you heard that I work for the other side?

question: What I heard is that you have your father's touch. And he was the only safecracker I knew who could open a Worthington 1000.
answer: I'm not a safecracker. I'm a professional safe and vault technician.

question: You're John Bridger's daughter. And this is our chance to set things right.
answer: Our chance? Who do you think you are coming in here? Stealing the gold isn't going to bring my father back to life.

question: No, it won't.
answer: Then get out.

question: How'd it go with the chick?
answer: I'm working on it.

question: I don't want her on the crew, Charlie.
answer: Gotta have her. Important piece of the puzzle.

question: There has to be someone else. What about Bill Huchins?
answer: Doing ten long at Levinworth.

question: Red O'Reilly?
answer: Chemo.

question: Martin Hernandez?
answer: Found Jesus.

question: I don't want a civilian to screw this up.
answer: She has the skill. And the motivation.

question: Exactly. She's emotional. You know what happens when emotion gets into it.
answer: It's emotional for all of us at this point. Don't kid yourself.

question: It's all in my patented sideways glance. Like this... I hit each woman on the jury with one of these. We make contact. And I know exactly what they're doing. Undressing me with their eyes.
answer: I see...

question: The case is all but won. That's why in jury selection I choose as many women as possible. Except lesbians, of course. I can tell in sixty seconds if they're a lesbian. Want to know how I know?
answer: If they don't undress you with their eyes?

question: Precisely. Like that waitress right there. See? She's looking at me right below my belt. Definitely not a lesbian.
answer: Your fly.

question: I think your date's going pretty well, what do you think?
answer: What are you doing here?

question: What do you mean? I come here all the time.
answer: I don't think so.

question: Sure. Lawyers, Judges, my kind of crowd. See that gentleman there, he sentenced me to 90 days in county once. We need to talk.
answer: No, you need to listen. I want you to leave. Got it?

question: Hey, I paid valet parking prices to get in here, not to mention a twenty spot to the busboy to spill that drink on Mister Zipper.
answer: You -- I don't believe this. You paid someone to spill that drink?

question: Actually, you paid for it. Didn't notice it was me who bumped into you earlier, did you? Anyway, I was hoping we could get to know each other a little better before we leave for Los Angeles. I already booked your flight.
answer: You truly are a fatuous, odious man.

question: I have no idea what you just said, but I like the sound of it.
answer: Well maybe you'll understand this. Hit the road, Jack --

question: Charlie --
answer: Or you'll be sorry, Charlie, cause I'll kick you in the nuts so hard that your voice will be as high as my heels.

question: I'm beginning to worry about this whole relationship.
answer: I'll let you in on a secret. You can't have a relationship with a pickpocket, gold robber, or any kind of thief.

question: Oh, sorry. I was just undressing you with my eyes. Hello.
answer: I'm in this for one thing, Charlie, and one thing only. I want to see the look on his face when his gold is gone. He took my father from me, I'm taking this; it's the best I can do.

question: I see Drive Defensively is your motto.
answer: Don't worry. Jack Daniels never let me down.

question: By the way you drive, I'm not surprised you named your car after a bottle of whiskey. Left.
answer: Jack Daniels was chief engineer of the Mini. And I drive it exactly the way it was meant to be driven.

question: Another left.
answer: We're going in circles. Who's tailing you this week?

question: The possibilities are endless.
answer: Where are they?

question: This is Stella Bridger. And we're finishing the job that we started in Italy.
answer: Holy shit. It's about time.

question: We need an in to get a video blueprint of the interior. We're not going into this place blind. Half-Ear, you take the first surveillance shift. Who goes in, who goes out, levels of security, you know the drill.
answer: You got it.

question: I also want audio surveillance on his phone.
answer: I'll hack into the phone company's central office remote observance monitoring system and fool it into thinking there's a legal tap on the line. Reroute the digital copies of his calls to our own listening post.

question: How long?
answer: I'll burn through the night, have it up and running before morning.

question: I'm sure it's ideal for carrying a ton of gold, genius.
answer: What's your guesstimate?

question: If we had all green lights, fourteen minutes. But in the twenty times I've done it, the average is thirty- two minutes, with a top time of fifty minutes.
answer: Then we'll travel like Rockefeller. When cars first started catching on, workers on tall ladders would use these swiveling colored boards for traffic signals. Now whenever Rockefeller would take the drive from his mansion to his office on Wall Street, the workers would make sure that he got green boards all the way.

question: How do we get all green lights?
answer: Lyle?

question: I'm telling you. He claims he named it Napster because his hair is so nappy underneath that cap of his. But I know the real reason. It's because I was NAPPING when he stole the idea from me. I should've been on the cover of Wired magazine.
answer: Would you clam up. You'd give a woodpecker a headache.

question: I'm the Napster.
answer: Okay. You're the Napster. Heads up

question: Becky. Nice name. I wonder what she calls the other one.
answer: And it's such a mystery why you don't have a girlfriend.

question: I had a girlfriend. Unfortunately even though the relationship ceased in an objective reality, it's still going on in my mind. That woman's lived in here rent-free for four years. Okay. All we need now is a work shirt like this one and a service truck like that one. You think Stella will be able to pull it off?
answer: I have my doubts, but there's no talking to Charlie.

question: Maybe he's been inserting his hard drive into her software. Clouds the judgment.
answer: He knows better than to mix business with pleasure. Only I'm allowed to do that.

question: Where you going?
answer: To get a work shirt and a service truck.

question: Hello.
answer: Yes, I'm calling from Adelphia Cable. I understand your service is out and an appointment was set up for Thursday.

question: Yes.
answer: Well we have a technician working in your area who finished with an appointment earlier than expected. Will someone be there for the next hour?

question: Sure. That'd be great.
answer: Our technician will see you then. Have a nice day.

question: You too.
answer: Let's check the camera.

question: Let's check the camera.
answer: Stella, you're going patriotic today.

question: He's got cable lines in the kitchen, living room, bedroom and a cable modem on the computer in the office. Try to get a 360 look at each room. And walk slowly or the image will streak.
answer: I printed these up to look like paperwork from Adelphia. When you're done, ask him to sign and date the bottom.

question: Philly Steak sent you?
answer: That's right.

question: So was I right-on about the gold bricks or what?
answer: That's really not what I'm here to talk about. Philly Steak said you could get us some supplies.

question: What do you need?
answer: A four inch can of Nitramon. Nitramon primer. Detonating cord. Two triple charger chemical grenades. Launcher.

question: Nine p.m.
answer: Should we hang here? Check out the dancers?

question: Nothing's going down here. I don't shit in my own yard, do you?
answer: No, but I take a whizz off the deck sometimes.

question: It's all right. They won't bother you now.
answer: It's okay. I'm used to running into all sorts of dogs on my job.

question: I'm Steve.
answer: Becky. You want to show me the problem?

question: Yeah. Course. This way.
answer: I'd like to check the cable modem first.

question: I'll show you. The cable guy who hooked this up weighed about 300 pounds, didn't wear any underwear, and his pants slung a little too low if you know what I mean.
answer: There we go. Now onto the TVs.

question: Is it fixed?
answer: Turn it on and see.

question: Perfect.
answer: Then it looks like you're all set.

question: Have we met before?
answer: I don't think so. Sign here, please. Date.

question: You read my mind.
answer: Oh, no. I meant that I need you to put the date by your signature. It's the 26th.

question: I know what you meant. This might seem a little sudden, but... would you like to have dinner with me?
answer: I don't think that'd be a very good idea.

question: Why? Is there some kind of cable- rule against dating customers?
answer: No, it's my rule. I don't accept dates from men I've just met. I've only known you five minutes.

question: Skinny Pete.
answer: The guy makes Jabba the Hut look like a spokesman for the Subway Sandwiches' diet.

question: What do you think?
answer: I'm trying not to.

question: And him, Handsome Rob.
answer: That's only cause he is Handsome Rob.

question: And I'm The Napster.
answer: How far? The Napster.

question: Five hundred yards.
answer: So here's the riddle. How do we get over a ton of gold from the vault to the getaway car?

question: You're early.
answer: And I'm in a hurry, okay?

question: Of course the Florida vote rigging was a CIA and Mob operation.
answer: That a fact?

question: You want facts? Fact Now given the sordid history in Miami of joint ventures between Central Intelligence and the Mob, which led to the unsuccessful attempts to kill Fidel Castro and the successful assassination of your President John F. Kennedy, this conjunction raises numerous red flags.
answer: And I'd love to hear more about it, but like I said...

question: Don't worry, we'll have you out in no time. The cash is on its way.
answer: On its way?

question: My cousin is bringing it over.
answer: Your cousin?

question: Yes. Cousin Mashkov.
answer: He's on his way?

question: Don't worry, he will be here any minute.
answer: The tape's off?

question: Of course. Believe me, he doesn't want to be on video, either.
answer: Yevhen. Didn't I tell you, many times, that I never wanted to meet with anyone but you?

question: I know. But it's his cash. He uses me to launder money. I'm just a middleman.
answer: And a middleman is supposed to stay in the middle.

question: But you were early. Please. Don't worry. It will be fine. My cousin's a cool guy. Like I am.
answer: What you are, is a Dixie cup.

question: My cousin Yevhen was beaten to death.
answer: By who?

question: That's what I'm going to find out.
answer: And what will you do when you find this piece of shit who killed your cousin?

question: I'll hack off his limbs and bury him while he's still alive.
answer: Okay. But now we should stop talking Ukrainian, it's rude to my girl. (switching to accented

question: Okay. But now we should stop talking Ukrainian, it's rude to my girl. (switching to accented
answer: Hungry.

question: Then eat your Frosted Flakes.
answer: They're grrrreat!

question: Do I get to drive one?
answer: No.

question: Why not?
answer: Because you can't navigate your way out of a parking lot. Here's your ride.

question: But he ran into me.
answer: He's not driving either. You ever got a speeding ticket?

question: What's the word on Rockefeller?
answer: The Traffic Control Center is on the top floor of a building on Olympic and Grand. They get their data from pavement loop detectors and video image vehicle detectors. That info is fused together by specially designed algorithms to predict traffic conditions and control the traffic lights. So all I have to do now is change the data by creating my own algorithm.

question: What can I do to help?
answer: I need to hard-wire into the mainframes. B4 X TTratio, where Bi are Fisher's linear discriminant function coefficients, SpdRat is the speed ratio, and TTratio is the travel time ratio.

question: I have no idea what you're doing. Just do it fast.
answer: We own this place.

question: You want the safe cracked, don't you?
answer: Yeah.

question: Then I have to have perfect nails.
answer: Are you making this shit up?

question: You really make laugh.
answer: So here's what I have lined up for after dinner. We'll go to Club Deep. The Ferrari always gets me to the front of the line. We'll do a little dancing...

question: Not tonight. I don't want to be out late.
answer: Why the curfew?

question: Let's just say I've made some wrong calls in the past. I like to take things slow, cautious. Next time...
answer: I understand. You have nothing to worry about. You can trust me.

question: I trust everyone. It's the devil inside them that I don't trust.
answer: That's an interesting saying.

question: What?
answer: There's only person I've ever heard say that. Used to say it all the time.

question: Who was that?
answer: A man named John Bridger. Where did you pick up that phrase?

question: Ow. I don't remember. You're hurting me.
answer: John Bridger was a thief. And he had a daughter. About your age. He told me that she took over a safe and lock company that he used as a front.

question: Let go of my wrist. What is wrong with you? It's just a saying.
answer: No wonder I liked you right away. Just like I liked your old man, right up until the moment I shot him in the head. Now tell me who you're working with and tell me the plan. Do it now or we'll go for a ride and I'll break every bone in your body.

question: Do you know who I am?
answer: You work for Danya.

question: Yes. And you are gonna be straight with me and everything's gonna be okay. You fuck with me, I will be ruthless.
answer: I understand.

question: I don't want you to understand. I want you to overstand.
answer: Overstand... Okay.

question: Not so fast. This is good news for us.
answer: Good news?

question: Sometimes when you're up to your ass in alligators you forget that you started off trying to drain the swamp.
answer: Meaning what the fuck?

question: We've been trying to get to the gold in the safe. Now the safe is coming to us. We'll boost it in transit.
answer: Charlie. He could take a dozen different routes to the airport and we have no idea which one. We can't take out an armored truck during rush hour.

question: Hello?
answer: Why'd you do it?

question: Philly Steak. Do what?
answer: Yevhen. The Ukrainian gold, dealer. You didn't, have to clip him, for Christ's sakes.

question: Clip him?
answer: Listen to me. You've gotta get out of L.A. Now.

question: What're you talking about? We didn't clip anybody.
answer: Well Skinny Pete just called me. Yevhen's cousin is under the distinct impression that you did.

question: Why does he think that?
answer: Because you wanted, to know about the gold with the Balinese Girl. Plus I guess Pete was under duress. This Ukrainian thinks he's Paul Fucking Bunyan.

question: Do you know how to get in touch with him?
answer: Yeah but...

question: Maybe there's a way we can play this to our advantage.
answer: Are you out of your mind? Listen to me, Charlie. Get out of L.A. Now. Cause if there's one thing I know, it's that you never mess with Mother Nature, mother-in-laws, or mother- fucking Ukrainians.

question: Did you know Einstein's 7th grade teacher told him he was a moron who'd never amount to anything? Same as mine.
answer: Still hope for that Nobel Prize.

question: Not me, man. But I did get my college diploma.
answer: No shit. I thought you dropped out of high school.

question: Got my GED after Italy then just kept going.
answer: How'd you manage that, all the jobs we've been pulling?

question: Quit going to strip clubs. Went to night school instead. City college is all.
answer: Good for you. That's a real feather in your cap.

question: I didn't want to say anything to the guys.
answer: Secret's safe with me. Napster. How goes it up there? Over.

question: You okay?
answer: Ah huh. Just need a moment's meditation.

question: Now?
answer: I'm about to insert a wire into a detonator tube and if the wire touches the sides of tube, we'll be blown to Kingdom Come. Best to be at one with yourself.

question: Take all the time you need.
answer: My work here is done.

question: How're we going to figure out which truck has the gold?
answer: You can monitor the traffic video cameras from your laptop, right?

question: Yeah.
answer: Where's the first camera the trucks will go past?

question: Cahuenga Boulevard. They all have to cross that.
answer: The weight of the gold will lower the suspension on the truck.

question: Lyle's fingers dance across the keyboard.
answer: Opening up a space on North Highland.

question: Via a traffic video camera, Lyle sees on his laptop the gold truck, followed by two motorcycles, making the turn onto North Highland.
answer: He's taking it... I now command you to turn left.

question: He's striking keys, an orchestral conductor, the crew his audience.
answer: I've got it on Hollywood Boulevard. Time to slow down.

question: Lyle has hacked into the Metro Rail's Control System. Starts his magic.
answer: Shutting down the rail as we speak.

question: His laptop shows a group of still circles that represent the stalled Metros.
answer: Tunnel's clear. Go!

question: Through his sideview mirror, Lyle eyes the progress of the gold truck. He gives the word:
answer: Coming into position...

question: The gold truck getting closer.
answer: Five... Four...

question: The gold truck is almost alongside the U-Haul.
answer: Three... Two... One... Do it.

question: Trust me. You wanna look.
answer: He spots the proverbial daylight at the end of the tunnel. In the teeth of gunfire. Bullets explode through the back window in a cacophony of CRASHING GLASS. A shot wings his door. POP! Into headset:

question: Split up!
answer: He sees someone give him the finger. Mutters:

question: Take out your gun and drop it on the floor.
answer: Who are you?

question: You knew my cousin. Yevhen.
answer: I never knew anyone named Yevhen.

question: Get in the trunk. Not that trunk, this one. That gold is for us. A gift from some old friends of yours. They said to tell you that they didn't mind sharing the box of Cracker Jack, as long as you didn't get any. Not even the toy surprise.
answer: Please. Don't shoot me. Please...

question: Don't worry. That wasn't the deal. I'm not going to shoot you.
answer: Thank you. Thank God.
